newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Ex-Rhodesian denies Palme murder accusation.
newsitem.headline: Ex-Rhodesian denies Palme murder accusation.

text.p: A former Rhodesian special forces soldier named as the assassin of Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme dismissed the allegation on Monday as "nebulous and far-fetched".
"I can only express extreme shock and disappointment (at the allegation)," Ant White told Reuters in a telephone interview from his timber business in Beira, Mozambique.

South African Dirk Coetzee, self-confessed leader of an apartheid-era hit squad, told Swedish journalists over the weekend that he had heard White carried out the murder of Palme in Stockholm in 1986.
Palme was a staunch opponent of the white minority government then in power in South Africa and his killer has never been brought to book.
White said Coetzee's statements carried no weight.
"It's untrue, I was not involved. I do not even have to defend myself, there's nothing for me to defend myself against," White said.
"The very people who made these allegations will soon retract them because they are so nebulous and far-fetched...
"I'm making myself available to the appropriate authorities so they can investigate and vindicate me," White said.
Asked where he had been in 1986, White said: "I was probably at home with my family on the day Palme was killed."
He said he had no idea why Coetzee, who he said he had never met, had spread the allegations.
White's former commanding officer in the Selous Scouts, a special forces unit that fought to keep Ian Smith's white government in power in the then Rhodesia, described him as an excellent soldier.
"We're all totally pissed off at these cowards who are trying to put the blame onto everyone else," said Ron Reid-Daly, who is now living in Johannesburg.

Coetzee's successor at the security police dirty tricks unit, Eugene de Kock, rekindled speculation about who killed Palme when he told a Pretoria court last week that fellow-agent Craig Williamson was to blame.

Williamson, who has admitted to three bombings against anti-apartheid activists, strenuously denied the accusation. He and White worked together in the 1980s in a company called Long Reach which was involved in intelligence gathering for Pretoria.
